title: The remark section sources consists of the basis material used for this topic and additional information for further reading. In addition you will find the full source codes for the examples there. Please pay attention that to make the source code for the examples more readable and shorter it refrains from things like error handling etc. It also passes on some specific language features which would obscure the clarity of the example like extensive use of advanced libraries etc.

title: There are numerous strategies for this problem, letâ€™s look at some:

inline_content.Text: There are numerous strategies for this problem, letâ€™s look at some:

title: Least recently used (LRU)
b
: Evict page whose most recent access was earliest

inline_content.Text: : Evict page whose most recent access was earliest

title: Least frequently used (LFU)
b
: Evict page that was least frequently requested

inline_content.Text: : Evict page that was least frequently requested

title: Longest forward distance (LFD)
b
: Evict page in the cache that is not requested until farthest in the future.

inline_content.Text: : Evict page in the cache that is not requested until farthest in the future.

title: Flush when full (FWF)
b
: clear the cache complete as soon as a cache miss happened

inline_content.Text: : clear the cache complete as soon as a cache miss happened

title: There are two ways to approach this problem:

inline_content.Text: There are two ways to approach this problem:

title: offline
b
: the sequence of page requests is known ahead of time

inline_content.Text: : the sequence of page requests is known ahead of time

title: online
b
: the sequence of page requests is not known ahead of time

inline_content.Text: : the sequence of page requests is not known ahead of time

title: Even though
LFD
b
is optimal,
FWF
b
has fewer cache misses. But the main goal was to minimize the number of evictions and for
FWF
b
five misses mean 15 evictions, which makes it the poorest choice for this example.

title: Now we want to approach the online problem of paging. But first we need an understanding how to do it. Obviously an online algorithm cannot be better than the optimal offline algorithm. But how much worse it is? We need formal definitions to answer that question:

inline_content.Text: Now we want to approach the online problem of paging. But first we need an understanding how to do it. Obviously an online algorithm cannot be better than the optimal offline algorithm. But how much worse it is? We need formal definitions to answer that question:

title: So the question is how
competitive
b
is our online algorithm compared to an optimal offline algorithm. In their famous
book
a
http://www.cs.technion.ac.il/~rani/book.html
Allan Borodin and Ran El-Yaniv used another scenario to describe the online paging situation:

inline_content.Text: is our online algorithm compared to an optimal offline algorithm. In their famous
Allan Borodin and Ran El-Yaniv used another scenario to describe the online paging situation:

title: There is an
evil adversary
b
who knows your algorithm and the optimal offline algorithm. In every step, he tries to request a page which is worst for you and simultaneously best for the offline algorithm. the
competitive factor
b
of your algorithm is the factor on how badly your algorithm did against the adversaryâ€™s optimal offline algorithm. If you want to try to be the adversary, you can try the
Adversary Game
a
https://pastebin.com/u/kgoedde/1/Wak9refA
(try to beat the paging strategies).

title: A marking algorithm (implicitly or explicitly) maintains whether a page is marked or not. At the beginning of each phase are all pages unmarked. Is a page requested during a phase it gets marked. An algorithm is a marking algorithm
iff
b
it never evicts a marked page from cache. That means pages which are used during a phase will not be evicted.

it never evicts a marked page from cache. That means pages which are used during a phase will not be evicted.

title: Proof:

Let Ïƒ be an instance for the paging problem and l the number of phases for Ïƒ. Is l = 1 then is every marking algorithm optimal and the optimal offline algorithm cannot be better. We assume l â‰¥ 2. the cost of every marking algorithm, for instance, Ïƒ is bounded from above with l â‹… k because in every phase a marking algorithm cannot evict more than k pages without evicting one marked page. Now we try to show that the optimal offline algorithm evicts at least k+l-2 pages for Ïƒ, k in the first phase and at least one for every following phase except for the last one. For proof lets define l-2 disjunct subsequences of Ïƒ. Subsequence i âˆˆ {1,â€¦,l-2} starts at the second position of phase i+1 and end with the first position of phase i+2. Let x be the first page of phase i+1. At the beginning of subsequence i there is page x and at most k-1 different pages in the optimal offline algorithms cache. In subsequence i are k page request different from x, so the optimal offline algorithm has to evict at least one page for every subsequence. Since at phase 1 beginning the cache is still empty, the optimal offline algorithm causes k evictions during the first phase. That shows that
